post.body: Hello ZeroMe!

Hello ZeroMe! I just uploaded my ZeroSite and need seeds! Red Liberty, a Libertarian Marxist Blog:

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CoVgJCDb588bVtxU9VAwGLGuybzdr3mfg/ 

I have already mirrored the clearnet site over I2P, Tor, Freenet, and now ZeroNet! I just need a few seeds and it'll be good! I hope you guys enjoy! There's a lot of writing here. It's 100% SFW unless you live in China or some insanely authoritarian country. I would appreciate seeds. Socialism or Barbarism, Liberty or Death! Freedom is always the freedom of dissent!

For forty-three years of my conscious life I have remained a revolutionist; for forty-two of them I have fought under the banner of Marxism. If I had to begin all over again I would of course try and avoid this or that mistake, but the main course of my life would remain unchanged. I shall die a proletarian revolutionist, a Marxist, a dialectical materialist, and, consequently, an irreconcilable atheist. My faith in the communist future of mankind is not less ardent, indeed it is firmer today, than it was in the days of my youth.

Natasha has just come up to the window from the courtyard and opened it wider so that the air may enter more freely into my room. I can see the bright green strip of grass beneath the wall, and the clear blue sky above the wall, and sunlight everywhere. Life is beautiful. Let the future generations cleanse it of all evil, oppression, and violence and enjoy it to the full.

Leon Trotsky.
Mexico February 27th 1940


While I am not personally an atheist, I nonetheless always appreciated the man and this letter of his. It is beautiful.

New post on Red Liberty!

Title: Activism and Revolution: Thoughts On Hong Kong and The PRC

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CoVgJCDb588bVtxU9VAwGLGuybzdr3mfg/

New post on Red Liberty!

Title: Mass Media In The Modern Age: Big Problems, Big Solutions

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CoVgJCDb588bVtxU9VAwGLGuybzdr3mfg/

Socialism or barbarism, Liberty or death!

Reading the comments on ZeroMe I found someone accusing me of "currently being engaged in CIA coverups counter lintel operations". A baseless accusation to be sure, and quite an absurd one at that.

Honestly I worry about the mental health of some of the people here on ZeroNet. With some people there's lot of conspiracy theory talk and weird behaviors like the aversion to certain words. Most people here are likely of sound mind, but I do have my doubts about some of them.

Historically the CIA has acted as the sort of "anti-socialist terrorizing force of the world" so I don't see how it's logical that a socialist would ever help them. I think truly being against terrorism should extend to terror in all its forms, including that orchestrated by the US military and CIA. 

For those not too familiar with the history of US foreign policy, here's a map of US Military and CIA interventions since WW2. Note this is actually pretty outdated so it's actually worse. Here I am in favor of a kind of glasnost in the US and the world. In my view WikiLeaks is the only true "intelligence organization" of the people.

If you live in a relatively free country, feel free to safely "help distribute this users images". While often political, you can rest assured that all our images uploaded will be 100% SFW (safe for work).

“When people talk of the Freedom of Writing, Speaking, or thinking, I cannot choose but laugh. No such thing ever existed. No such thing now exists; but I hope it will exist. But it must be hundreds of years after you and I shall write and speak no more.” -John Adams to Thomas Jefferson (15 July 1817)

Adams here didn't actually realize he was talking about what one day would be the censorship resistant internet. If you are reading this then you are using it, welcome!

Apparently the US government hasn't learned why mandatory backdoors are impossible for ensuring any degree of security or privacy. Literally every cryptographer in the world who knows anything about cryptography will tell you why mandatory backdoors are a horrible idea. Politically, we at Red Liberty say the same for key disclosure laws and "national security letters" being served to US tech companies (see LavaBit).
The trial against Assange is a trial against the first amendment and a war on freedom of the press. #FreeAssange

If you're tired of "fake news" and want good, reliable, consistently adversarial journalism I cannot recommend The Intercept (https://theintercept.com/) enough. Most media organizations try to be objective until it comes to matters of state. The Intercept tells truth to power.

We just launched a site on immigrants' rights in the United States with info and PDF's put up by the ACLU. If you support human rights please seed it! 

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HAiyXKpGjUxydg8DvrXKc4yB33k4Mv7iA/

Did ZeroNet just explode? There are SO MANY MORE people on here than usual (stats and noticed activity). But are they all from 8chan? I don't really know how to feel about this. So here's a mixed welcome:

Arf Arf! Fuck Off Nazi's! Everyone else, Welcome to ZeroNet!

"With sword in hand and ready to defend themselves, the people of Hong Kong can strike while the iron is hot, write the rule-book themselves, and dare to dream dangerously. Let them do so now without bloodshed, let the government bow before the people’s will for this is right. Let them do this now or tomorrow! The people cannot be stopped! People of Hong Kong, the city belongs to you and to you alone! There is no authority but that which derives from yourselves! Freedom loving people the world over stand with you! You are not alone!"

comment.body: The EFF is a great organization, I'd take what they say to heart. Privacytools.io is also a really good resource.
For what purpose if I might ask? Also, did you verify signatures and checksums?

@caryoscelus: That's upsetting. I will seed over Tor when I am able to but it may be a week or so. Currently I am not using ZeroNet over Tor because I live in a relatively free country and want maximum performance.
@caryoscelus: I will look into this
@caryoscelus: I see, I'm working to fix the issue. Any idea what could cause this?
@caryoscelus: I fixed it! Site should be up now!
@Quantumworld: Oh rats! I will upload a picture of Winnie The Pooh shortly.
#SorryNotSorry
Obligatory "I use Arch" comment.
@Quantumworld: Rats! Good thing he can't DDoS me on ZeroNet!
@Quantumworld: I didn't know the people of Argentina had democratic control over their economy and workplaces. That is what socialism is after all.
@Kiloromeu: lol https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Libertarian_Marxism
@Quantumworld: ?

@Kiloromeu: I just find it ironic how ignorant most people are in regards to what 'Marxism' even is. Marxian political economy and Marxian economics are merely a critical, yet extremely thorough scientific analysis of the capitalist system. From Marx's critique of capitalism, countless schools of economic and political thought have come about, all attributing themselves in one form or another to the ideas of Karl Marx. From the most anti-authoritarian variants of anarchism to the most totalitarian, anti-liberty forms of Stalinism-- all of which claim to be attempting to address the very real ills and undemocracy of capitalist society. 

Let me give you some context.

There are today published, 50 volumes containing pretty much the entire economic and sociopolitical writings of Marx and Engels, each volume is about 500 pages each. Do you know how much of that speculates as to what a socialist or communist society would look like? About 7 pages, and even those 7 pages appear radically democratic in scope. Did Marx draft a "master plan" for the construction of a liberated society? No. He speculated, but his go-to phrase was "I do not have a crystal ball". Marx always said, "If you want to know the future, go to the local fair and pay a fortune teller". 

Do you want to see his appraisal of his "ideal" social revolt in embryo? It happened during his life time. Read his writings on The Paris Commune, which he praised for arming the common working people, abolishing the police as a political institution, making all public servants democratically elected on the basis of universal suffrage and instantly recallable by popular petition-- receiving no more than a workman's wage. He praised the commune for taking state power only to begin the process of the destruction of the state. Every elected official had an extremely short term of service. His "ideal" social revolt is today praised by many anarchists, and Marx criticized the neo-Jaconins who wanted to re-create the reign of terror of the first French Revolution. Is it revolution that offends you? This tradition was continued under Rosa Luxemburg, who critically supported the Russian Revolution, the worlds first workers and peasant revolution of the poor and oppressed who at the same time, fervently condemned the dictatorial methods of the Bolsheviks in the name of Marxism. She said,

"On the other hand, it is a well-known and indisputable fact that without a free and untrammeled press, without the unlimited right of association and assemblage, the rule of the broad masses of the people is entirely unthinkable…

Freedom only for the supporters of the government, only for the members of one party – however numerous they may be – is no freedom at all. Freedom is always and exclusively freedom for the one who thinks differently. Not because of any fanatical concept of “justice” but because all that is instructive, wholesome and purifying in political freedom depends on this essential characteristic, and its effectiveness vanishes when “freedom” becomes a special privilege...

When all this is eliminated, what really remains? In place of the representative bodies created by general, popular elections, Lenin and Trotsky have laid down the soviets as the only true representation of political life in the land as a whole, life in the soviets must also become more and more crippled. Without general elections, without unrestricted freedom of press and assembly, without a free struggle of opinion, life dies out in every public institution, becomes a mere semblance of life, in which only the bureaucracy remains as the active element. Public life gradually falls asleep, a few dozen party leaders of inexhaustible energy and boundless experience direct and rule. Among them, in reality only a dozen outstanding heads do the leading and an elite of the working class is invited from time to time to meetings where they are to applaud the speeches of the leaders, and to approve proposed resolutions unanimously – at bottom, then, a clique affair – a dictatorship, to be sure, not the dictatorship of the proletariat but only the dictatorship of a handful of politicians, that is a dictatorship in the bourgeois sense, in the sense of the rule of the Jacobins (the postponement of the Soviet Congress from three-month periods to six-month periods!) Yes, we can go even further: such conditions must inevitably cause a brutalization of public life: attempted assassinations, shooting of hostages, etc. (Lenin’s speech on discipline and corruption.)”

Keep in mind here that Rosa Luxemburg, a “Libertarian Marxist” by today’s standards, was in fact, in her time, nothing more than an Orthodox Marxist. Her writings if read today, would be seen as radically libertarian by modern American standards, yet they were Marxist through and through. Our fight is for democracy at work, and for local democracy. We want to bring power to the streets where the people live, to towns and communities, popular assemblies against centralized state power. We want an armed people, ready at every moment to defend their liberty from all external threats. We want to expand the liberty that exists today, adding positive liberty to negative liberty. We desire not "free markets" but free, emancipated labor, a free association of producers. Yes, we desire communism, free, stateless communism.

If you read my ZeroSite you would see that we have an entire page dedicated to this topic (http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CoVgJCDb588bVtxU9VAwGLGuybzdr3mfg/libmarx.html)

What do you associate with the word "Marxism"? My guess is not at all what we are talking about. Some form of Stalinism, that in modern political discourse is equated with the ideas of Karl Marx? They do not teach such things in schools for a reason. What more can I say? Ignorance wins yet again.

@Quantumworld:

 "I am a proud X-Communist and a very high ranking one."

What does "a very high ranking" ex-communist even mean?

"I think you need to learn the rules of Communism."

There are rules? I never read that.

"There is only one Dictator that maintains group think communist control."

Do you mean like in Stalinist Russia? Do you not understand that we are just as opposed to Stalinist totalitarianism as we are to Capitalism?

@Quantumworld:  "heard those claims allot. Communism looks good on paper but when practiced it fails totally do to non equal compensation to the amount of work being done."

Ah yes, the "works on paper" argument. Where exactly has communism been practiced? The early Apostles? Or do you mean the totalitarian one-party states of the 20th century which only claimed to have achieved socialism (really more state capitalism), and in those countries the official motto was "He who shall not work, neither shell he eat" or "from each according to their ability, to each according to their work" which is the motto of socialism as differentiated from capitalism where the propertied classes can amass great fortunes without working themselves. So basically the argument for socialism is precisely that of equal pay for equal work, and communism of social goods to each according to their need (implying a post-scarcity society likely utilizing automation, i.e. where we are heading).

"Basically everyone get the same pay regardless what you do. So there is no incentive to do jobs that many people do not want to do because it is the same pay."

Pretty much no one thinks this, most thinkers speculate that those who do said jobs would be given first access to luxuries. We are after all, talking about a post scarcity society. If you mean to say that Stalinism is the same as "Communism", even in those societies pay was more egalitarian but a Doctor still made substantially more than a Janitor, as per the philosophy of socialism.

"Then you have the group think mentality. Where one Jerk in the group can just jam up everyone else in the group from doing anything because they need a 100% majority vote. Meaning that nothing ever gets done."

Where exactly did you here that? I no of no such communist philosophy, even a Stalinist one that insists on a 100% majority vote, this is quite an absurd claim. Industrial democracy can take a variety of different forms, including the election of those who manage an enterprise on a higher level. Political democracy? Is that what you are arguing against? I am unsure what you are referring to. As for nothing getting done, we are talking about local, direct democracy. Even the Stalinist countries which lacked that, (what I you seem to be referring to as communism) were known for ruthless efficiency (i.e. the philosophy of dragging a country industrially into the 20th century from semi-feudal barbarism kicking and screaming). Later stagnation of course being due chiefly to a near total lack of democratic methods of industrial management. 

"I have read just about every communist book that is in English made."

I somehow doubt that, I don't know of anyone who can boast such a thing.

"When communism is practiced, corruption, theft, and out right lying between communist members becomes a normal practice and it eventually destroys the state."

Well the word 'Communism' implies a stateless society, something you would certainly know if you were as knowledgeable on the subject as you claim to be, with all due respect. If you are referring to the 20th century Stalinist states, even to the early democratic aspirations of the Russian Revolution, what can you expect from an extremely impoverished country? Name for me a single poor country today that is not rifled with corruption. What do you mean by communist members? Parties? You do know that even many Marxists are against the use of political parties right? Once again there has never been a "communist country", it's an oxymoron. Stalinist? Yes. But communist? No. Totalitarianism in political life and state-capitalism in economic life is about the farthest thing from socialism or communism you can have.

"Now is capitalism perfect? Absolutely not. And the U.S. has not been a capitalist country since 1913. The U.S. is run by crony capitalism currently."

You should know that the definition of capitalism is "private ownership of the means of production" in an industrialized society. You hear this argument from right-wing libertarians a lot. We know that the economic growth and stability of "fully free markets" is naught. If you look at the most successful forms of capitalism in the world, look to China. That is our future under capitalism. The thing I hate about "libertarian" free market fundamentalism is that it often takes a Stalinist attitude towards its own failures. When the devastating effects of its own policies are revealed, the right libertarian, like the Stalinist, demands only a more complete adherence to their ideas.

"A private bank controls the U.S. economy. The state gave up its right to make money, and turned it over to a hidden private banking cartel that is a fascist predatory lender. Its called the Federal Reserve."

Capitalist banks are evil? Who knew? There are a lot of conspiracies about this kind of thing out there you know. Be careful with that.

"Unless you have some new philosophy that fixes Communism it will fail every time." 

Lol

"No country is capitalist at this time in my view."

We are using the Marxian term, also the term used in Keynesian and Neoclassical schools of economic thought (all pretty widely accepted in one form or another) and not some esoteric Austrian school that hardly any economist takes seriously.

"I cannot say and will not say how high up I was in the Communist party. When you leave the party they try to kill you. That's just a fact about Communism. It is a brutal system of slavery."

Once again, lol. What country do you even live in? You speak English so I am assuming America or one of the Five Eyes nations. Which Communist Party? I know plenty of people who enter and leave this or that party at a whim as their views change. A murder? That would make headlines! Once again we are anti-Stalinist, anti-authoritarians. A free association of producers in a stateless society based on political and industrial democracy and unlimited individual liberty is slavery? But work for a propertied class for poverty wages or starve is not? Lol.

@Quantimworld: Please understand that I mean not to offend or insult you in my replies. I can be a bit crude in my debating at at times, I hope you can forgive that. I am sure you care about the world as much as I.

@Quantumworld: I had a feeling that is what you were talking about. I know all about the Rothschild conspiracy theories. A lot of people who hear about it or even believe it aren't anti-Semites themselves, but it historically is an anti-Semetic conspiracy theory. Blaming "bankers", especially "wealthy Jewish bankers" instead of looking at the broader socioeconomic system is pretty common among right libertarians, conspiracy theorists, and I see it in neo-Nazi circles as well. It is a great way to get people to look away from the bourgeoisie as a class and towards an insignificant part of it. Are banking institutions a fundamental part of the capitalist system? Yes. I find it quite absurd to insist that those fighting to abolish the capitalist system, and the "banking system" at the same time are funded by them. It's like saying the Monarchy funded the Jacobins, or the Tsar funded the Bolsheviks. Yes, wealthy capitalist bankers are funding communists. Lol

@Molibdenio: “We are convinced that liberty without socialism is privilege, injustice; and that socialism without liberty is slavery and brutality.”

― Mikhail Bakunin 

To many of us modern socialists, the two are inseparable. One cannot truly exist without the other. Laugh today if you will. Tomorrow the revolution will “rise up again, clashing its weapons,” and to your horror it will proclaim with trumpets blazing:

I was, I am, I shall be!
@Yzabella: Thank you! :)

@SSDifnskdjfnsdjk: We should act like pissed off conservatives who love their guns, who non-nonchalantly with rifle at their side say "come and take it, I want to see you try". Snowden spoke of turn-key tyranny. Perhaps the key turns much slower than he feared, and in my view that is even worse. You can kill a frog by boiling him slowly in a pot of water, but plunge the from into boiling hot water and he will leap out immediately! Maybe we are like the frog here, perhaps this is more terrifying than merely turning the key to tyranny. If congress openly passed NSA spying legislation the people would have made a revolution! But because they did it in secret, how did the people react when they found out "oh they have been doing it all along, big deal"? It's a sad state of affairs.

@Quantumworld: Well respectfully, I doubt the credentials of an "informed critic" when they spell "Stalin" as "Stallen". It is sort of like arguing about the inner mechanics of Keynesian economics by saying "Canesian economics". Or talking about the specific, technical aspects of how Tor works by saying "TOR" instead of "Tor". It's just a major red flag that says "You haven't REALLY investigated this objectively for yourself, familiarizing yourself with both sides of the argument". I mean no offense, I appreciate the feedback, positive or negative, more encouragement to do the research for yourself (I probably would have argued the same thing when I was much younger, and you yourself may come to the opposite conclusions as I did and that's okay too). 

And also, what is meant by communism? You seem to imply that Stalin's USSR was a communist society, not even Stalin made such claims. If you read Stalin's own constitution it defines the USSR as socialist embodying the philosophy of "from each according to their ability, to each according to their work" (i.e. not everyone is paid the same, as was never claimed by any regime). As for "only works with a dictator with a gun", one can look at anarcho-communist Spain or Czechoslovakia during the Prague Spring. Also "the same low wages" is an interesting argument since communists regard capitalism as a necessary stepping stone in order to usher in a post-scarcity era where it is even conceivable to speak of abolishing wage labor (not the "same" wages) and having a society productive enough for all to give according to their ability and take according to their needs (i.e. communism).

@Nickwa: Precisely

@Nickwa: They certainly have been. Bush started this descent into digital authoritarianism after 9/11. Before Obama it was largely condemned by the democrats (even if legislation such as the infamous Patriot Act enjoyed bi-partisan support). After Obama it became largely bi-partisan. Post-Snowden the veil was lifted off of many people's eyes. Obama wasn't about change at all. Today you have anti-establishment democrats (yes such as Sanders and AOC) in addition to anti-establishment conservatives (right-wing libertarians such as Ron Paul) standing against it, but other than that it has become mainstream. 

It's an interesting united front on the issue with leftists such as myself (mostly of the anti-authoritarian variety) and right-wing libertarians. It's an explicitly up-down rather than a left-right politics on this issue. I would say Pelosi and Trump are just about in agreement on the issue, AOC or Sanders and Trump not so much. But I don't think they hold the views we do, at least to the extent that we do either. I think much of the contemporary left though is often (though not always) as idiotic on the issue of political censorship as Trump, and as if not more idiotic on privacy when they aren't the ones needing it. I am proud to say that Red Liberty stands apart in that regard (see my post condemning the corporate censorship of Alex Jones as but one example and numerous posts in defense of the necessity of the cypherpuks movement, privacy, censorship resistant networks, etc). Often it's a "it's bad when they do it, good when we do it". It's a totally insane notion.

@Moor: Yes it is, all accessible from yours truly over I2P at marxists.i2p. I suppose I could try to mirror it on ZeroNet as well but there may be logistical problems. I have never done this for a site that large and I would need a moderately fast external drive to store the sites files (assuming I could make ZeroNet do that) as my 24/7 ZeroNet node doesn't have NEARLY the space necessary to handle it. On top of that I still need to update my I2P mirror with the latest version of Marxists.org (mine is about 8 months out of date), so once that is done then yes I suppose I could try!

@Moor: Oh it really is! You will find virtually every socialist, communist, anarchist, and left-ish view espoused in addition to a TON of old documents relating to the old liberalism of the 18th century, classical economics, and the like. Also media too! SO MANY .pdf and audio files. I kind of wish it was the "Politics Internet Archive" so every view could be espoused but alas, 400+GB is already pressing the upper limit of what I can host. I used a VPN connected to mirror it with wget and it took literally over a month to mirror the whole thing with a second gap between each file download so robots.txt wouldn't block my IP! It was a monumental task.
@Moor: Did you see any 404 deadlinks or just "We can't display this bc copyright"? Maybe someone will build such a thing on one of these networks unbound by copyright legislation, but I doubt it.
